characters: INT. HALLWAY OF LODOVICO STREET DAY
EXT. WINDOW OF TORTURE ROOM DAY
EXT. A PEDESTRIAN TUNNEL, NEAR WATERLOO NIGHT
INT. TORTURE ROOM FROM LANDING DAY

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The bare bulbs in the room we've entered swing violently, disorienting us.  There are chains - dozens of them - disappearing with the darkness of the ceiling: all are swinging back and forth.  Some end in hooks, with pieces of skin and sinew adhering; some are serrated, others simply drip blood. The bell tolls on. On the blood-spattered floor, a box, some six inches square, which resembles an elaborate Chinese puzzle box.  Later, we'll learn its name and function. It's called the Lament Configuration, and it's a way to raise Hell.  LITERALLY. For now, it remains an enigma. A hand, its flesh systematically pierced with needles, reaches down and picks the box up. In close up we see just what an elaborate construction it is, made up of sliding panels and mysterious chambers.  It is open at present, its polished innards exposed.  Out of it, a banal melody, played on a hidden mechanism.  The hands, which belong to one of the demons - a CENOBITE - move over the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unseen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over ... Delicately, the hands begin to reconstruct the box, sliding the well-oiled parts back into place, the tune simplifying with each manoeuvre. The room is getting darker.  The chains are disappearing into the gloom. We see tantalizing glimpses of other figures, turning from the light and fading into the darkness.  We catch sight of monstrous faces, but only for the briefest of moments.  Then they're gone. The box is almost returned to its unopened condition. The last sounds to fade are the tune from the box, and the bell. It tolls on as the final panel of the box is slid into place. The light stops swinging. The panel clicks.  The tune stops. At last, a long shot of the room.  At the far end the window is covered with yellowed newspapers.  There is dust settling through the air. Otherwise it is empty. The bell fades. It's as if nothing ever happened here. Except ... Somewhere, very quietly, a creaking that could be the sound of floorboards, or the low, agonized gasp of a thing barely alive.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: The wind is blaring as we watch the door of Number 55. From the doorstep, voices.  One is that of LARRY COTTON, the other his wife JULIA.  Clearly LARRY is attempting to get inside.  We hear the sound of keys tried in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to freeze to death.

dialogues.speaker: 0.K. 0.K.
dialogues.text: The sound of another key tried in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe somebody changed the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a thought -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! The key is turned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Success. The door swings open. Voila! We see the pair on the doorstep.  LARRY is an American in his early forties, an attractive man who has lost his edge in recent years.  He looks harassed; he smirks too much.  A little, but significant, corner of him is utterly defeated.  JULIA, his wife, is English: and looks perhaps ten years his junior.  She is beautiful, but her face betrays a barely buried unhappiness.  Life has disappointed her too, of late: and LARRY has been a major part of their disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  This is it. They step over the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: The door of the Torture Room creaks, as the wind blows it opens an inch.  From downstairs, we hear JULIA's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It smells damp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just been empty a while.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY slams the front door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: The Torture Room door creaks closed again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from below)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, it's an old house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: He stands in the hallway, not certain which way to go from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long since you were here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best part of ten years. LARRY picks up some mail - circulars mostly - from behind the door, then leads JULIA through from the hallway to explore the ground floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to sell it off at one point, after the old Lady died, but I couldn't get Frank to agree. He opens one of the doors, and looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pleasure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.  It's not been touched. He continues along the passageway.  He opens another door, and steps into a large room.  He opens one of the curtains.  Light pours in, dust-laden shafts falling on the sheeted furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this. JULIA lingers in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he want to sell it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Probably wanted a hideaway. He pulls a sheet off a chair. Look at this stuff. The chair is ugly; old fashioned.  JULIA is unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly modern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll sell it.  Sell everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought half of it was your brother's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't complain.  He can pay off some of his creditors. LARRY is getting more enthusiastic about the place by the moment.  He leaves the room, moving past JULIA to explore further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know we have to let Kirsty see this place, before we do anything to it.  She'll love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean we're moving in? LARRY pauses.  Looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like it? JULIA shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than Brooklyn. She turns back down the hallway. He watches her, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still blaming me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to come back to London.  We came back. We are hearing the tip of a debate they've had dozens of times, which immediately annoys them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the argument?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ.  Julia ... JULIA wanders back to the bottom of the stairs.  Then starts to climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated, to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA climbs the stairs, her face charged with suppressed feeling.  She's sick of LARRY; his enthusiasm depresses her, his compromises anger her.  What's between them is stale, like this house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: The door opens a fraction.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY has stepped into the kitchen, to find the remains of the food we briefly glimpsed in the titles sequence, now rotted and fungal.  It smells, to judge the expression on his face.  It also puzzles him. Then, from above:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry! He leaves the kitchen and retraces his steps to the bottom of the stairs. Larry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you. He starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY reaches the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of sight)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here. LARRY follows JULIA's voice to the end of the corridor. JULIA is standing in a doorway.  Beyond, the 'bedroom' we saw in the titles sequence, untouched since then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squatters? LARRY steps past her, and throws back the blankets. Wood-lice scurry away.  He goes to the suitcase, and starts looking through it.  Besides clothes there's a lot else that speaks of its owner: bric-a-brac picked up in a lifetime of adventuring; handful of bullets; Fragments of an erotic statue; coins and notes from a dozen countries.  Amongst the stuff, some photographs. LARRY peers at them.  One pictures a good-looking intense man in his mid to late thirties, in bed with a naked Chinese girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. At the door, we see JULIA almost flinch at the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been here.  There's stuff in the kitchen.  He must have made a hasty exit. The 'phone rings downstairs.  JULIA jumps. That'll be Kirsty. LARRY stands up and leaves the room, moving past JULIA in the doorway, who is left to stare down at the bed FRANK has slept in, and the suitcase of belongings. As we hear LARRY clatter downstairs it seems JULIA's face is close to tears.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNSTAIRS ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: The 'phone continues to ring.  LARRY steps through and picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ...? There's no answer. Hello ...?

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANK'S 'BEDROOM' DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA goes to the open suitcase, and looks at the photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on'phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anybody there? He puts down the 'phone.  He goes back out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANK'S 'BEDROOM' DAY
dialogues.text: Nervous that LARRY will return and see what she's doing, JULIA is going through the photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from below)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody there - The sound of his foot on the stairs.  Hurriedly, she selects a photograph of Frank without the girl, and pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRS DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY is climbing the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised it's even connected ... The 'phone rings again. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANK'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Mission accomplished, JULIA leaves the bedroom, taking one last glance at the sweat-stained sheet and the indented pillar where Frank lay.  A lone wood-louse crawls over the sheet, navigating the folds.  She closes the door on the sight.  Downstairs, the 'phone stops ringing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNSTAIRS ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY has picked up the 'phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: INT. KIRSTY'S ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: KIRSTY, the daughter of Larry's first marriage, and his only child, on the 'phone.  She is barely twenty, beautiful in an unpretensious way: a dream of a girl- next-door.  We can't see much of the room she's in at the moment, the shot is too tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on 'phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said: I found a room. We begin to draw back from KIRSTY now, as she continues t speak to her father.  She's sitting on a battered chair by the door.  The room she's in is cramped and dirty. From outside, the sound of trains going by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to stay with us for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd like the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU'D like my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to come over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  Not just yet.  It needs ... er ... some work. That it does.  The place, now we've got a good view of it, is a total dump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I want you to see the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to change my mind, Dad. As she speaks she reaches forward to pull a picture, tacked to the wall, of a ourangoutang, with breasts collaged onto it, down.  She succeeds.  Beneath there's a large hole in the wall, which the picture was there to conceal.  Plaster falls from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouths the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well come over, will you? See the place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow.  I got to go look for a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. Honey. Well you take care. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too. She puts the receiver down.  As she does so the small table on which the 'phone is sitting collapses.  She covers her face with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY OF LODOVICO STREET DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA is three steps from the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles; he's pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll move in Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNSTAIRS ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A church bell rings.  Off-screen, we hear voices: two men are attempting to move a bed into the house with LARRY masterminding the manoeuvres.  We HEAR their efforts, but we don't yet see them.  Our interest is in JULIA, who is unpacking a tea-chest in a room which is still full of draped furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to get it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tip it!  Tip it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  Wait!  Watch the fucking paint work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, do you want the bed in or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take it slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sod you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, Chas, slow it down like the man says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Famous last fucking words. JULIA's face through this has been almost devoid of expression.  She's holding so many feelings inside; deep inside.  Now she moves from one box to another, and opens it to find it full of bathroom bric-a-brac. She picks it up and goes through into the hallway. The bell continues to ring.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: The three sweating men have the bed wedged in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not seeing Julia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's give it another try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees Julia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really need this bed, lady? LARRY turns.  Sees JULIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing through there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like a bomb's dropped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some in the 'fridge. Nobody moves to get it.  Certainly JULIA has no intention of being waitress.  She goes to the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. LARRY disappears through into the kitchen.  JULIA starts up the stairs, watched appreciatively by the two men in the doorway.  One leans over and whispers to the other, who laughs.  JULIA glances back at them. The whisperer licks his lips; the meaning of the gesture perfectly apparent.  JULIA heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NUMBER 55 DAY
dialogues.text: KIRSTY arrives at the head of the drive.  The two men are drinking beers.  The bed has not been moved. She wanders down the drive towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Kirsty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my lucky day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to buy a bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. She moves past them, attempting to insinuate herself between the bed and the door-jamb.  They watch, enjoying her efforts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? LARRY emerges from one of the rooms, looking harassed. His face lightens as he sees his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey! They hug each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me like. Another hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you around when we've got this damn bed moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Julia here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs. (his voice lowers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treat her gently, huh?  She hates moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a gently chiding voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K.  I'll be nice.  You get on with the muscle work.  I'll make myself some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitchen's through on your left KIRSTY kisses LARRY, and goes through to the kitchen. LARRY turns back to the door.  The men have been watching KIRSTY.  LARRY clearly dislikes the scrutiny. 1ST MAN, out-stared by LARRY, looks away.  The 2ND MAN is unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins oafishly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got her mother's looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother's dead. 2ND MAN's grin fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia's my second wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right.  Now are we going to move the bed or not?

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN DAY
dialogues.text: The kitchen is chaotic.  Cutlery, crockery, utensils, pans and foodstuffs have been heaped on every available surface.  KIRSTY has found the kettle, but is having difficulty turning on the tap.  She struggles with it.  No joy.  Just a rattling sound in the pipes as the system lurches into action.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: The pipes rattle and chug behind the plaster.  The CAMERA moves along the corridor, hugging the wall. At the end of the corridor stands JULIA, in a patch of sunlight.  She has the photograph of FRANK in her hands. She looks intently at it. A CLOSE-UP of the photograph.  Then FRANK's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in? JULIA looks up from the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JULIA'S FLASHBACK DAY
dialogues.text: A front door opens.  On the step of another house stands FRANK, with two suitcases.  It's raining outside; HARD.  The rain has plastered his hair to his scalp, which only emphasizes his raw good looks. He's unshaven; his eyes are dark, and intense. Again, the line she remembers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in? The splash of rain on the step becomes a spurt of water, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the present day.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN DAY
dialogues.text: The tap has come on suddenly, spraying KIRSTY with water.  She jumps back, soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!  Shit! She reaches to turn the pressure down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: The men are struggling with the bed again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls through)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: Again, JULIA returns her gaze to the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JULIA'S FLASHBACK DAY
dialogues.text: The same scene:  FRANK in the doorstep.  Now we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the person who opened the door.  It's JULIA; a younger JULIA, her hair arranged differently, her clothes brighter.  It is two weeks before her marriage to LARRY.  She looks at the man on the doorstep without a trace of recognition on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Julia, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a dazzling smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm brother Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came for the wedding. He looks at her, eyes glittering.  His hold on her is almost mesmeric. There is going to BE a wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well can I come in or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  Of course.  You're very welcome. He steps inside.  Now he is close to her, rain running down his face.  We can hear his breath; sense the almost intimidating intimacy of his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice to know. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a towel?

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA stares down at the photograph.  Off scrren, KIRSTY's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a towel? JULIA looks up.  At the top of the stairs, KIRSTY soaked from the tap.  JULIA looks up, and hurriedly pockets the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  I got soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a towel in the bath- room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to your left. KIRSTY ducks into the bathroom.  We

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA.  It's clear the memory of her first meeting with FRANK has affected her deeply.  The tears that threatened earlier are close.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM DAY
dialogues.text: KIRSTY has unbuttoned her blouse and is drying herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Dad tell you I got a room, by the way?  Waterloo.  Centre of the known universe. Silence from outside. Julia? (she puts her head out of the bathroom)

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA has gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: The door of the Torture Room is pushed open.  JULIA steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: KIRSTY hears the creak of footsteps on the boards above.  JULIA's behaviour puzzles her, but she's not about to waste time thinking too hard about it. She starts downstairs again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: We have an odd, hovering point of view of JULIA, as she steps inside the room.  Something about the atmosphere distresses her. There is a scratching sound.  She looks down.  A wood-louse, recalling Frank's foresaken bed, crawls along the edge of the skirting board.  She crosses to the window, and tears away a little spy-hole in the aged newspaper. From downstairs, the voices of the bed-movers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it.  I told you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  Wait! The light through the window falls on her eye. The screen becomes a white-out, from which emerges:

dialogues.speaker: INT. JULIA'S FLASHBACK DAY
dialogues.text: A bedroom, with afternoon sunlight pouring between the slats of bamboo blinds.  Outside we can hear children playing summer games.  Inside, a fly buzzes. JULIA, the younger self, is holding her wedding dress in front of her, displaying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see the dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see the dress. JULIA lets the dress drop a few inches in front of her.  She stares at FRANK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I want. Still she doesn't let the 'defence' that the dress offers - a reminder of her imminent marriage - fall. She stares though, and there's an invitation in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you. Now we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK.  He is not so beraggled as in the first scene, but the heat of the day has brought a sheen of sweat to his face.  Standing half in shadow he looks almost dangerous. Now JULIA lets the dress drop, putting it on the bed behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better FRANK steps towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Larry -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget him. FRANK takes hold of her.  She doesn't resist him, though there is barely disguised fear on her face. He puts his hand inside her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: In extreme CLOSE UP, JULIA blinks into the light through the window, as LARRY's voice from downstairs calls her from her reverie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, will you?  Slowly! Again, a white-CUT, from which emerges:

dialogues.speaker: INT. JULIA'S FLASHBACK DAY
dialogues.text: The two are naked on the bed, both sweating now. Beneath them, the wedding dress, crushed under their weight. Their love-making is not straight-forward: there is an element of erotic perversity in the way FRANK licks at her face, almost like an animal, his hold on her too tight to be loving.  The sequence escalates into a series of strange details from their locked bodies.  Nails digging into palms; sweat rivulets running down their torsoes.  And once in a while we see their faces.  JULIA watching FRANK, mesmerized and amused by his intensity; FRANK almost pained by his desire to push the experience TO THE LIMIT.  Their passion is rendered stranger still by the way the light through the window falls on their bodies, making striped creatures of them. At last, as their urgency increases, we move up until we're looking directly down on the bed. From here it is JULIA's face we can see, and the ecstasy of the moment has seized her.  Her arms are flung up over her head; her eyes are closed as she murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.  Oh my God.  Oh my God. The scene whites out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA is still staring into the light.  She sobs, very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Frank ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Downstairs, LARRY and the men have moved the bed across the hall to the bottom of the stairs. All three are weary now, and getting careless. As they start up the stairs we see trouble ahead for LARRY, whose hand is moving closer and closer to a nail proturbing from the woodwork of the bannister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Movers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take the weight while I take a step up? He backs towards the stairs - and the nail. Damn it, will you take the - The side of his hand is impaled bythe nail.  He cries out.  The weight of the bed, which he cannot relinquish, drives the nail deeper, and gouges a long cut from the ball of his thumb to his wrist.  Blood pours out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fucking hand! He drops his edge of the bed, and disengages his hand from the nail upon which he's injured himself.  He lifts his hand, from which blood is pouring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking ass-holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you calling a fucking ass-hole?  It's this bastard bed that's your fucking problem! LARRY isn't listening.  He's looking at the wound in his hand.  He hates the sight of his own blood. Any moment, he may faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh Christ ... But not in front of these bastards.  He turns and starts up the stairs, groggier by the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... oh ... Christ ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA is standing in the middle of the room.  A single dart of light, through the hole she tore in the newspaper, strikes her face.  Softly on the soundtrack, the scrabbling noise of the woodlice.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: The bed has been put down.  1ST MAN and 2ND MAN are putting on their coats.  KIRSTY comes through from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fucked off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock chiding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh ... LANGUAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  He's gone upstairs.  So we're fucking off too. 2ND MAN takes a sheet of paper from his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sign for the bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRS DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY, his hand running with blood, climbs the last flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Julia ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA hears him, and turns from her silent communing with the room.  She crosses towards the door.  Too late. It opens.  LARRY steps inside, blood pouring from his right hand, which he attempts to staunch with his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut myself. Blood has started to drip, unnoticed by either of them, onto the bare boards.  Heavy splashes. LARRY looks sick; his face clammy with sweat.  She stares at him without a trace of feeling for him on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it deep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I haven't looked. You know me and blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're NOT going to faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he leans againts the wall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see. She goes to him.  He looks away as she unglues one hand from the other, and looks at the wound.  Blood comes fast hitting the floor between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably going to need stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not. The blood keeps hitting the floor.  Slap; slap; slap. We'll get you out into the fresh air. He is again clamping his hand over the wound, as JULIA helps him to the door.  They leave the Torture Room. We hear their voices receding down the passageway, as we again assume that hovering view point.  The floor, is heavily spattered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So damn stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're done worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be scarred for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you won't.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: KIRSTY is half way up the stairs, as JULIA and LARRY head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an accident.  He's all right.  Will you drive?  He needs stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The keys are in the kitchen. KIRSTY heads back to the kitchen.  JULIA helps LARRY towards the front door. The CAMERA swings away from them, upstairs, and begins to track ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: ... we continue to track, towards the Torture Room. Downstairs, the front door slams.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: From outside, the sound of a car door slamming.  An engine starts.  The car drives away. We move towards the blood on the floor.  As we watch, it begins to disappear, as if being absorbed by the room.  We pan up to the wall.  The plaster is not quite smooth; indeed, it now begins to grow restless, and cracks.  Something begins to move in the wall ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: An explosion of laughter.  We CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the remains of a rack of lamb, its gravy now congealed, scraps of meat adhering to the bone here and there. This is the centre-piece of a table reduced to a battlefield by the guests who are laughing off-screen. We pass along the table, taking in dirty plates and cutlery, napkins, glasses and emptied wine bottles. Finally, we reach JULIA, who is still sitting at the table, while the others have retired to more comfortable seats.  She looks utterly miserable, and a little drunk. The room has been spruced up for the party.  Candles are burning on tables and mantelpiece, there are pictures on the walls.  But this is essentially cosmetic.  The place has not been refurnished or re- decorated. We move to the party guests.  Two, we recognize: KIRSTY, and LARRY - who is presently entertaining the gathering with an account of his accident.  The others are new faces.  An American couple:  BILL UNDERWOOD and his wife EVELYN, who are of an age with LARRY, and a younger, bespectacled man - a work colleague of LARRY's - STEVE O'DONNELL.  All are drunk. A brandy bottle sits on the table between them, and half a dozen other liquer bottles besides.  STEVE, it soon becomes apparent, has his eyes on KIRSTY. LARRY is half-way through his hospital story, gesticulating wildly as he goes through the tale, much to the pleasure of the rest.  His hand and lower arm are heavily bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - always hated the sight of my own blood.  I go out like a light. Anybody else's?  no problem.  But mine ... you know ... goes straight to my head.  Anyhow, this damn doctor's poking around and I'm saying: I'm going to pass out, and he's saying, no you're not, no you're not.  Next thing I know - We

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA, who watches her husband, unamused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I wake up On the floor. Gales of laughter at this. And it was HIM who was looking sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably thought you'd sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  And he's saying: I'm sorry.  I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE'S sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right ... (he has picked up the brandy bottle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone for more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protests)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you're only young once - LARRY fills up her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kirsty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you drinking, love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on the Cointreau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Cointreau. STEVE picks up the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it. He fills up KIRSTY's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be able to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So lie down. She casts him a sly glance.  He smiles.  She smiles. JULIA now stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me?  I think I'm going to go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you O.K.? JULIA nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.  I think it's time we were away - He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill?  Absolutely not.  Sit down.  We've got celebrating to do. JULIA looks frosty, but LARRY does not catch the look. KIRSTY does however.  BILL sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Julia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a wonderful meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gushing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh it was.  It was wonderful. There's a chorus of approval.  JULIA puts a smile on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  You must.  We're so happy you're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.  Well ... goodnight. She exits, to a chorus of goodnights.  KIRSTY in particular watches her as she makes her exit.  JULIA's behaviour confounds her.  Meanwhile, the conversation has returned to LARRY's 'wound'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it still hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I laugh. This wins another round of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING NIGHT
dialogues.text: JULIA walks along the landing, while the laughter - muted by distance - wafts up from below. From the floor above, she hears something more. She stops, puzzled, then starts up the second flight of stairs towards the Torture Room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING NIGHT
dialogues.text: She approaches the Torture Room, and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The sound of laughter is considerably dimmed in here; it's barely audible.  But there is another sound, a shifting sound in the corner of the room. She reaches for the light switch, and turns it on. The bulb's been broken however.  She stares around the room, trying to make sense of the shadows. Nervously, she approaches the wall, on which four streaks of light from the window fall.  Now she looks towards the window and realizes that the newspaper has been torn, as if by four fingers.  Her breath catches.  Suddenly, she's afraid. She stands absolutely still, eyes wide in the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there? On the far side of the room, a movement in the shadows. JULIA almost retreats, but something keeps her staring into the murk, as SOMETHING - the remnants of a human form made of twisted, blistered strands of flesh, raises its head.  It's squatting against the wall, unable to lift itself into a standing position.  Its eyes, however, have life in them: and hunger. This, though he's unrecognizable, is FRANK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pained whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said: don't look. She looks away. Help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. JULIA's face registers horror and disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  God no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me.  It's me.  It's really me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His blood ... on the floor ... It brought me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back from where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just help, will you?  Please God, help me - From downstairs, dimly, laughter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: LARRY has just told another story.  General drunken laughter.  KIRSTY stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just upstairs. She staggers a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need any help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I AM house-trained. Further hysteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covered in embarrass- ment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... I meant ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's round on the left -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. She steps out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: She starts up the stairs.  She smiles to herself, thinking of STEVE.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: FRANK, in the corner of the room, watches JULIA, who is still at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... somebody ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh! The sound of KIRSTY downstairs, closing the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't let me stay like this. Please.  You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blood brought me this far. I need more of the same.  Or I'll slip back ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA's lace as she stares at FRANK once more.  She is appalled at the choice before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a plea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to heal me.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: KIRSTY smiles at herself in the bathroom mirror, turns off the tap, opens the door and steps out onto the landing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING NIGHT
dialogues.text: She takes a step along the landing, then realizes that there's somebody ahead of her, in the darkness. She stops.  From the floor above, a soft sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? JULIA moves out of shadow into a patch of patterned light splashing up the stair well.The effect recalls her memory of her lovemaking with FRANK.  The light makes her look strange; ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you. JULIA doesn't smile Are you all right? Do we read murder in JULIA's eyes?  KIRSTY is uneasy. Suddenly, a voice from the floor below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsty? KIRSTY is relieved at the interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we'd lost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming! (to Julia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well. JULIA is left on the landing, as KIRSTY heads downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TUBE STATION NIGHT
dialogues.text: The station is deserted, but for KIRSTY and STEVE, who are sitting, waiting for the last train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I do know the way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  I want to see you home.  All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do if there isn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We walk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A PEDESTRIAN TUNNEL, NEAR WATERLOO NIGHT
dialogues.text: KIRSTY and STEVE are walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you stay at Larry's house?  There's plenty of room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there's room.  And there's Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so damn ... English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.  Up-tight. Frigid. STEVE stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ya go. (imitates his tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not all frigid. KIRSTY has turned to look at him.  Both of them are aware where the banter is leading; smiles play on their faces as they speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves closer to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you've just been talking to the wrong people. He kisses her, with considerable feeling.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: LARRY snores loudly.  JULIA lies beside him, wide awake, staring at the ceiling. LARRY turns over, muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The door opens.  JULIA is standing there, in her night-gown. FRANK raises his wretched head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? JULIA stares at the thing moving in the shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NUMBER 55 DAY
dialogues.text: The door opens.   JULIA steps out of the house, and starts towards the street.      As she does so, she glances round.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WINDOW OF TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: We approach the window, knowing that FRANK watches behind it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NUMBER 55 DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA heads off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PIZZA RESTAURANT DAY
dialogues.text: The din of a lunchtime restaurant, with all the tables full, and everyone hungry.   In the middle of the melee, KIRSTY is valiantly trying to do six things at once.  Somebody wants their order taken;  somebody else wants more lager;  somebody else is complaining. She's doing her best, but losing the battle.  She serves a table with their food, and then starts back to pick up another order.   As she does so she's harangued from every side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like some more lager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? KIRSTY starts back to the counter.  As she does so somebody else's voice cuts through the din.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sex-bomb - She wheels round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep your - (sees Steve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just called in.  How about tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't finish till twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a late riser. He grins.  She grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have to do to get some service around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch you later.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR DAY
dialogues.text: By contrast, a quiet bar.   Discreet music;  a well-dress clientele.  Several couples occupy booths.  Other solitar drinkers are at the bar. Amongst them:   JULIA. Now we see her more closely, we realize she's gone to som considerable effort to make herself ravishing.  There's nothing crude about the change;  it's a subtle transforma which shows off her considerable beauty.  She drinks soda water. She has an admirer.   Sitting alone at one of the tables is a middle-aged man by the name of PRUDHOE, a nervous, slightly paunchy individual.  She glances over at him. Hi eyes don't leave her for a moment.  He's trying his best to get the courage to approach her. She looks away, and concentrates on her drink.  Now she takes out a cigarette, fumbling for it. Her hands are trembling slightly.  She lights the cigarette, draws on it, and as she does so she seems to make up her mind that she's not the equal of it.  She stubs the cigarette out, puts cash on the bar for her drinks, and gets up to leave Suddenly, PRUDHOE's at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much fun, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinking alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder, maybe ... He's so nervous he can barely speak. ... as we're both on our own ... we could have one drink together? JULIA looks at him.  He seems to almost be offering himself to her.   There's a long pause, while she tries to make up her mind. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? She smiles.   The smile works wonders.  PRUDHOE's nerves diminish somewhat.  JULIA's simply increase, now that she's committed herself.  Again, she opens the pack of cigarettes, as PRUDHOE calls the BARMAN over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Julia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plain soda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try not to drink at lunch- time.  Makes me sleepy in the afternoon.  You like to keep a clear head, eh? (to Barman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One soda, one whisky. (to Julia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do it anyway.  No will-power. Got a busy afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking straight at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? He stares at her, not certain he interprets her correctly She stares back.  Then: the tiniest of smiles, which he - scarcely believing his luck - returns.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: The CAMERA moves across the room. We can hear FRANK's ragged breathing, and as we move in we see, on the floor beside him, the box - the Lament Configuration - its sides gleaming.  FRANK, still squatting on the floor, taps a tattoo on the bare boards with his skeletal finger Then, voices outside:  JULIA laughs. He raises his head.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOORSTEP DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA opens the front door.  She is still very nervous, fumbling with the keys.  PRUDHOE stands a pace behind her

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: They step inside.   JULIA closes the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it's not often I ... you know ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a first time for every- thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already way over my usual limit.  You know, it's funny. I feel like I've known you for years. He approaches her:  his gestures made slightly clumsy by the alcohol he's drunk.  He kisses her.  She presses him her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. (he takes hold of her breast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what you brought me here for, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I just think we'd be better off upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Oh fine.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTUPE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: FRANK's view, from the corner of the room.  We hear the sound of JULIA and PRUDHOE's approach up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No personal details, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're incredible - JULIA opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in.  Make yourself at home. She steps inside.  PRUDHOE does as he's instructed.  He stares at the bare floor, as JULIA closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time for everything, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. JULIA moves towards him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take off your jacket? You're warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why don't I? She slips the knot of his tie.  We can hear her pulse on the soundtrack.  She glances over PRUDHOE's shoulder.  He follows her gaze, but she diverts him with a peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes over his undressing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you do the same?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I will. PRUDHOE, now starts to shed his jacket and trousers, tryi not to take his eyes off JULIA for an instant. We watch from FRANK'S P.O.V. as he drops his underwear. He still wears his shirt, which he starts to unbutton. We move back into a tighter shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice slightly slurred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you are.  Loveliest woman I ever set eyes on. JULIA smiles. PRUDHOE stops unbuttoning his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much drink.  Better empty my bladder. She steps out of the way so that he can cross to the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be a moment. As he moves to the door, she throws a piece of cloth off a hammer, which lies beside the wall.  PRUDHOE takes hold of the door handle.  Turns it:  it's stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door's stuck. Before he can turn she hits him on the back of the head. He doesn't fall, but the blow sends blood down the back of his shirt.   To avoid the following blow he stumbles blindly towards the wall but JULIA's not going to be stopped now.  He holds the back of his head - dazed, apologetic, pitiful - while she moves towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ... I ... please ... I'm sorry ... She eclipses him. ... I'm so sorry ... She raises the hammer. ... I don't understand ... She strikes him.  He slides down the wall, his jaw broken, blood pouring from his face.   He twitches.  Then the twitches stop. She drops the hammer, and stares down at the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough? The room sighs.   In the corner, FRANK's shadowy form leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me. JULIA backs towards the door, as the broken, skeletal form crawls out of darkness to claim its sustenance.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA steps out onto the landing and leans against the wall, waves of sheer relief breaking over her. In the room behind her, terrible sounds of feeding.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA steps into the bathroom, and looks at herself in the mirror.   Blood is spattered on her face;  her hands are similarly stained.  She is trembling from head to foot. Stripping off her blouse, and flinging it over the side of the bath, she douses her face, neck and breasts with cold water.  Then she stares up at her face again, examining it.  She can scarcely believe what she's done.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: She crosses the landing and climbs the stairs to the Torture Room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: She opens the door. As she does so FRANK retreats into the shadows.  We are granted a fleeting glimpse of him, his body fuller than before, but still horribly vulnerable. JULIA looks at PRUDHOE's corpse.  A trail of blood leads away from it into the darkness.  The body itself is a grotesquely misshapen husk now, the muscle and fat withered, the eyes sunk into the skull, the lips drawn back to expose the gums. A ghostly sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. JULIA looks across at FRANK, who is no longer sitting, but standing in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice stronger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I disgust you? She doesn't reply. He stretches his arm into a passage of light.  His flesh glistens and pulses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?   It's making me whole again. He turns his arm over for her appreciation. Every drop of blood you spill puts more flesh on my bones. And we both want that don't we? She nods. Good.  Come here. She stares, unable to move. Come here, damn you.  I want to touch you ... Still she doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to Daddy.  I only want to touch ... She takes a step towards his outstretched arm.   His fingers touch her face.  She steels herself against them. Now, he starts to trace the line of her jaw, stroking her.  Now her lips, caressingly. Suddenly, a sound from downstairs.  The front door is opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from below)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart? JULIA withdraws from his touch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from below)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Shot from the stairs of LARRY.  He looks up the flight. He takes a step towards the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA takes a step backwards, her foot hitting PRUDHOE's corpse.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY is still at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there? For a moment it looks as though he's going to climb the stairs, then he thinks better of it, and goes through to the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA has wrapped the corpse of PRUDHOE up in its clothes and is now lifting it.  The body is lighter now, having been drained of nourishment.  Its head lolls back and its dentures drop out, hitting the floor loudly.  She freezes No sound from below.  She backs out of the room with her burden. FRANK's arm reaches for the fallen dentures and peers at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's a pretty boy then? Soft laughter from the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JUNK ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA pushes the door of the Junk Room, which is on the upper landing, open.  Inside, a chaos of tea-chests and bric-a-brac.  She lays the body down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY has come through to look for JULIA.  He hears a noise above.   He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia? He leaves the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Again, LARRY Steps into the hallway, and gazes up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there? He starts up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA steps into the bathroom, and then locks the door behind her. LARRY ascends to the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from bathroom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart ... I've been calling you. He tries the door.  It's locked. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just feeling a bit sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, babe ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA, still trembling, sits on the edge of the bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be O.K.  Just leave me be a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe a brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be down in a minute

dialogues.speaker: O.K.
dialogues.text: She listens as his footsteps recede down the landing and stairs.    Then she crosses to the mirror and tries to erase the signs of panic.  She puts a comb through her hair, and adjusts her blouse.  That done, she unbolts the door and steps out into the landing.  She doesn't go down however, but UP,  back to the Torture Room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank? A crunching sound in the shadows.  FRANK's hand opens, dropping the pieces of PRUDHOE's dentures, which he has crushed, onto the floor, in a rain of plastic teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hurting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nerves ... are beginning to work again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more.  Maybe two - JULIA's face registers no horrer at this. - to heal me completely.   Then we can be away from here, before they come looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cenobites.  It's only a matter of time before they find I've slipped them. I have to get away from here. From downstairs, LARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia?   Are you all right? JULIA crosses to the door and calls down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment.  Put on some music will you babe?

dialogues.speaker: O.K.
dialogues.text: She returns to her conversation with FRANK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Larry.  Obedient as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down. She crosses to close the door.   When she turns round, he's in front of her, silhouetted against the window, his half-formed face terrifying in the gloom.  Suddenly he reaches out and catches hold of her arm.  She gasps in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh. Don't want babe to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hurting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't cheat me will you? You'll stay with me.  Help me. Then we can be together, the way we were before.  We belong to each other now, for better or worse ... He lets go of her. ... like love.  Only real. She goes to the door, and leaves him, locking it behind her. We move close to FRANK's face.   He licks his skinned lips with a bloody tongue.  Thunder rolls.

dialogues.speaker: KIRSTY'S DREAM
dialogues.text: The thunder carries over to a dream. We are in the Dining Room of Number 55, except that everything is once more shrounded in sheets. We CUT to KIRSTY, moving through the room, her face pale, her hair glued to her forehead with sweat. Somewhere, a bell is ringing.  Flies buzz.  On the dinner table, a form is covered in a sheet.  It's clear that the shape is human.  She reaches the table, and looks at the body. Suddenly, blood begins to seep through the shroud, beginn at the head - eyes and mouth - then spreading across the body.  There are sobs beneath the shroud. She reaches for it, to snatch it off the body. The blood has almost turned the sheet scarlet. She pulls. We glimpse only a moment of what'd beneath: a naked body, scarlet and shining with blood from head to foot. She screams. Her scream becomes louder, as we

dialogues.speaker: INT. KIRSTY'S ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: STEVE sits bolt upright in bed, while KIRSTY yells. The sheet is snatched off him.  He looks across the room to see KIRSTY at the end of the bed, with the sheet in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? KIRSTY's eyes are still closed. Kirsty! Her eyes open.  She looks down at the sheet she's snatche from the bed, and drops it in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.  What was that about? KIRSTY, weak with fear, just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, NUMBER 55 NIGHT
dialogues.text: A phone is ringing. LARRY crosses the hallway, bleary-eyed, and disappears from sight.   The phone is picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: JULIA lies in bed, the pillow empty beside her.   She's wide awake, staring at the ceiling.   Downstairs, the murmur of LARRY's voice.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: FRANK stands in the corner of the room, breathing softly in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TELEPHONE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: LARRY is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm O.K., honey.  It's all right ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. KIRSTY'S ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: KIRSTY is on the phone.   STEVE sits up in bed, having reclaimed the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to be sure you were O.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better.  You sleep well. KIRSTY (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, honey. KIRSTY (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too. LARRY puts down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOWER LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: LARRY returns to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsty. He goes into the bedroom. We PAN up the second flight of stairs. FRANK is sitting at the top, in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft as a breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsty.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: The front door is closed by JULIA.   A man stands in the hallway:  another VICTIM.   He is as nervous as PRUDHOE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure we're not going to be interrupted -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only I like to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A shock CUT to the naked VICTIM, thrown back against the wall from JULIA's hammer blow.  Before he can even slide down the wall, FRANK is upon him. We don't linger, but CUT away to:

dialogues.speaker: INT. LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: As JULIA closes the door, her face devoid of emotion, we see the VICTIM's body on the floor, with FRANK's hands oh its head, draining out its energies.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: JULIA sits, sipping a drink, her face still unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: FRANK is standing in the shadows.  The VICTIM's body is in the middle of the room. JULIA enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better.  Much better.  I'd like some clothes.  And maybe a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you tell me ... you explain what happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: We pan across the walls as FRANK speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted access to experiences ... pleasures ... that only they could offer ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cenobites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they call themselves. They're not human.  Maybe they were once, but they're not now. They rearrange their own flesh for pleasure. We've moved across to FRANK now.  He is dressed, in loose fitting jacket and trousers, through which his blood is seeping.  He smokes, taking great pleasure in the experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the box? FRANK picks up the box.  Vague, tantalizing forms move over the surface, like ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cost me a fortune.  All I had.  It's a puzzle you see. You solve it, and the Cenobites come through ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God knows.  Sometimes I think they're just behind the walls ... He turns the box over.  The lacquer catches the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they cheated you In the lacquer we see oiled bodies moving.  It's difficult to be sure what the forms signify.  Is this torture, or some elaborate pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.  They kept to their bargain.  They gave me experiences I'd never forget ... The images in the lacquer are becoming clearer, and they are APPALLING.  Flesh torn open; blood running across sweating flesh; hooks, and terrible machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But their pleasure was my pain. His voice has begun to tremble.  The images in the box are more horrific by the moment.  And flowing between them, highly distorted, the CENOBITE's faces, and that of FRANK, screaming and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible pain.  Appalling ... He can't speak for a moment.  After a pause, he goes on, his voice heavy. My body was forfeit.  But my spirit ... they left that here. In the boards.  In the walls. Watching the world, but never able to touch it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the blood let you out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are ways to resurrection. Blood's one of them.  I won't let them take me back, Julia. JULIA looks at the horrors in the box, and understands his desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be whole, and then get out - He lifts the box up. I won't let them take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't have to.  We'll be gone.  Somewhere they'll never find us. There's a rumble of thunder. Not in the whole wide world.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: More thunder, and the sound of heavy rain against the windows. The television is on.  LARRY and JULIA are sitting on the couch.  LARRY is watching a boxing match.  He has consumed several beers:  the cans are beside his feet; and there's another in his hand. JULIA reads a magazine, glancing up at the screen to see the match getting more heated.  Blood is starting to flow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this upsetting you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen worse. LARRY looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only I'll turn it off - There's a sudden raising of shouts from the screen, as one of the boxers hits the canvas.  LARRY turns his attention back to the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's down!  He's down! The thunder rolls on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TORTURE ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The lightning finds its way through the holes in the newspaper.  FRANK is watching through the window, his face occasionally washed with light.  His hand, on the window frame, taps out the same tattoo he's tapped out before.  He turns away from the window, and his foot catches the box.  It rolls across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The boxing match is heating up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and now he's in trouble, he's really in trouble -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that? JULIA looks up from her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder. The violence on the screen is horrific, as swollen faces burst beneath punches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Something else. LARRY stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I left a window open - She gets up and crosses to the door. - I'll go see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'll do it. He opens the door, and steps out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING NIGHT
dialogues.text: In such tight close up we can't sec that FRANK has in fact left the Torture Room, we see his features register that somebody is coming.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRWAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: LARRY is climbing the stairs.  JULIA follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nothing. LARRY has reached the top of the stairs.  He looks up the next flight. Larry ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you? She's desperate to stop him climbing to the Torture Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just hate the thunder. He crosses to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. He puts his arms around her.  She responds. You're shaking. He hugs her tight, kissing her lightly. The thunder shakes the house. There's nothing to be afraid of. He kisses her neck, his hands restless on her. I'll just go check upstairs ... He kisses her again.  She, in order to distract him, kisses him back.  Her passion is artificial, but he doesn't register that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me then. He starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPPER LANDING NIGHT
dialogues.text: He reaches the top of the stairs.  First he throws open the Junk Room.  Lightning flashes on boxes inside.  Then he moves towards the Torture Room. The thunder rolls more loudly. She follows him along the landing, desperate to stop him. Too late.  He throws open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. Lightning floods the room.  It's empty.  She stands beside him at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must have rats. She looks back down the stairs.  Where's FRANK gone? LARRY turns to her, holding her again, on the threshold of the Torture Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  Quite safe. He kisses her, much harder this time; a sexual kiss. Let's go  down.  I'll make it better. He kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: A shadow moves across the screen as the door opens, and LARRY puts on the light. He has hold of JULIA's hand.  He leads her inside.  She sits on the bed, illuminated by the light from the landing, and the occasional flicker from the window.  LARRY kneels between her legs, and kisses her breasts, his eyes closed. JULIA glances into the shadows of the room.  She senses FRANK's presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... oh babe ... He starts to unbutton her dress.  She's distracted by her suspicions; he has his hands against her almost before she realizes what's happening. We have her P.O.V. as she looks around the room.  The dressing table; the wardrobe; the curtains at the window.  Does something move in the shadows? A flash of lightning.  No.  There's nothing. LARRY gets onto the bed and draws her against him, kissing her.  This is not the intense, slightly dangerous love-making she experienced with FRANK, but a fumbling, slightly foolish exchange.  LARRY is so wrapped in attempting to make the right moves he doesn't register the fact that JULIA's attention is elsewhere. Now we have a P.O.V. from the far side of the room, of the two figures on the bed, the only sound the thunder and LARRY's murmured words of seduction, which we can barely make out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I love you, honey ... let me ... oh God ... I love you ... Neither of them have undressed fully; there's just a tangle of clothes around them which removes any trace of eroticism from the scene. A CLOSE UP of JULIA's head, laid on the pillow, shows just how uninvolved she is - while LARRY works, eyes closed.  JULIA looks down the length of her husband's body.  The door of the wardrobe swings open.  FRANK is watching.  She registers horror.  LARRY is oblivious to all of this, of course. We have a CLOSE UP of FRANK watching the love-making. Now he steps out of the wardrobe.  JULIA makes a moan of horror, which LARRY takes as enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
